docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Don't Get Up. She's Only Riding for 2,'' by Randy Kennedy (Tunnel Vision column, April 30): What's new about the subway riders who jealously guard the seats that cost them $1.50? How about Metro-North passengers, who pay several times that amount and don't get a seat?

headline.main: Where Courtesy Is as Rare as a Free Seat

docs.abstract: Janet Falk letter recalls how nobody gave her seat on packed Metro-North commuter train when she was pregnant and feeling ill (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Don't Get Up. She's Only Riding for 2,'' by Randy Kennedy (Tunnel Vision column, April 30):    What's new about the subway riders who jealously guard the seats that cost them $1.50? How about Metro-North passengers, who pay...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Don't Get Up. She's Only Riding for 2,'' by Randy Kennedy (Tunnel Vision column, April 30): Pregnant at nine months in July 1985, I too rode the subway to and from work in Manhattan. Like the author, I did my own informal survey and found that the majority of people relinquishing seats were young women.

headline.main: Where Courtesy Is as Rare as a Free Seat

docs.abstract: Debbie Goldschmidt letter reports that when she was pregnant and riding New York subway, most of people offering seats were young women; says strides toward equality do not justify steps backward in human decency (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof (''Devastated Women,'' column, April 26) portrays the terrible human cost of the president's decision to withhold $34 million for the United Nations Population Fund. This decision is puzzling considering previous strong support of the organization.
docs.abstract: Repr Nita M Lowey letter on human cost of Pres Bush's decision to withhold $34 million from UN Population Fund; warns lack of US support is crippling programs that save lives of millions of poor women and children around world by providing most basic health care (S)
